data.title: Dr. Dre
data.meta_description: No, they never “Forgot About Dre,” as proved by tributes the artist and producer won over the course of hip-hop’s 50th year. He was one of the honorees at the Recording Academy’s Black Music Collective event in February, and in June he received ASCAP’s Hip-Hop Icon award. data.text:
No, they never “Forgot About Dre,” as proved by tributes the artist and producer won over the course of hip-hop’s 50th year. He was one of the honorees at the Recording Academy’s Black Music Collective event in February, and in June he received ASCAP’s Hip-Hop Icon award. February also brought about the 30th-anniversary edition of his solo debut, “The Chronic,” with the album returning to original distributing label Interscope and, after being out of circulation for almost a year, streaming services. Bankers never forgot about Dre, either, as seen early this year in the news he was selling his catalog to Universal Music and investor Shamrock Holdings for an estimated $200 million. In August, Filipino-American rapper Ez Mil signed to Aftermath and Eminem’s Shady Records, while November saw Floetry member Marsha Ambrosius use the Soul Train Awards stage to remind fans that Dre is producing her next solo album.

From the distinction of becoming hip-hop’s first billionaire to being honored with a Hollywood Walk of Fame star this week, the accomplishments and confidence of the man born Andre Young — aka legendary producer-rapper-entrepreneur Dr. Dre — could best be summed up with the lyrics from his debut solo hit, 1992’s “Nuthin’ but a ‘G’ Thang”: “You never been on a ride like this before / With a producer who can rap and control the micstro / At the same...
